messageBody:
So as not to hi-jack the original thread, I changed the subject....

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Christian Pekeler [mailto:christian@...]
> Subject: Re: [junit] To mock final classes
>
>
> Just don't use final. In my opinion, final and private are the most
> counterproductive keywords in Java.

Could you elaborate a little more on this?

I can see how final and private methods would be counterproductive to
JUnit testing because those methods would be more difficult
(impossible?) to test.

Before I started junit testing a lot of my classes would look something
like this:

class MyNiftyClass
MyNiftyClass();
public SomeReturnValue doSomethingNifty();
public AnotherReturnValue doSomethingElseNifty();
private int aPrivateMethod(int param1, int param2);
private String anotherPrivateMethod(String param);

doSomethingNifty() and doSomethingElseNifty() are pretty easy to test
but the others are harder to test since they're private. I know there's
a way to test private methods using reflection I think but I haven't
bothered to look into it since it's probably kind of convoluted and
testing private functionality isn't really suggested.

But what do you do when aPrivateMethod() really is something you want to
test? From a recent topic, say aPrivateMethod() calculates the sum of
param1 and param2 and returns it? That's something that might be good
to test. You could refactor the private methods into their own class in
which they would be public methods. Now after JUnit testing for awhile
my classes are starting to look kind of like this:

class MyNiftyClass
MyNiftyClass(NiftyHelper helper);
public SomeReturnValue doSomethingNifty();
public AnotherReturnValue doSomethingElseNifty();

class NiftyHelper
NiftyHelper()
public int aPrivateMethod(int param1, int param2);
public String anotherPrivateMethod(String param);

Now all the methods are public and easy to test.

What does everyone think? Is this a good way to organize the classes?

Kris
